title: 103_hr1594
content: The "Deposit Insurance Reduction Act of 1993" reduces deposit insurance from $100,000 to $25,000. The "Deposit Insurance Reduction Act of 1993" lowers deposit insurance coverage from $100,000 to $25,000 for FDIC insured depository institutions. Trust funds are also affected by this change. The "Deposit Insurance Reduction Act of 1993" reduces deposit insurance coverage from $100,000 to $25,000 for FDIC insured depository institutions, with amendments to the Federal Deposit Insurance Act. The "Deposit Insurance Reduction Act of 1993" reduces deposit insurance coverage to $25,000 for FDIC insured depository institutions, with a transition period allowing excess amounts over $25,000 to be insured for one year. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation will regulate the notice requirements for insured depository institutions. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation will require insured depository institutions to notify accountholders of deposit insurance reductions and transition rules. The Corporation will enforce these requirements as the appropriate Federal banking agency. The term "insured depository institution" is defined for this purpose. The term "insured depository institution" is defined in the Federal Deposit Insurance Act. Amendments to the Federal Credit Union Act reduce insured deposits from $100,000 to $25,000. The effective date of these amendments is 60 days after the enactment of the Act. The National Credit Union Administration may allow excess amounts over $25,000 to be insured as deposits for a year after amendments reducing insured deposits to $25,000. Insured credit unions must notify accountholders of the reduced deposit insurance amount and transition rules within 60 days. The Board of Directors of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the National Credit Union Administration Board will prescribe regulations to implement the transition rules for reduced deposit insurance amounts.
